caption: If your the kind of person who loves the rare and off the beaten track experiences seize this opportunity before it gets on the tourist track. Take the 5 euro tour of an ancient Parisian cellar! Learn what life was like a eight hundred or so years ago in Paris.  Buy a beautiful map in the main room.

This place is great, especially if you like history. There are few vestiges of medieval Paris left, and this is one of them. They have lots of old map reproductions for sale, but the best part is, for only 2 Euro, they will give you a guided tour of the medieval cellar and a later 15th century part of the structure. Very informative. I had a personal guided tour by a knowledgable young man who works there. If you like history and off the beaten path museums this place is not to be missed!

If you enjoy history or medieval times, or have an interest in ancient Paris, France, visiting Ourscamp, Paris, is worth a visit.  This is among some of the oldest construction in the city.  One can see restorations in progress, as well.  This organization is providing a vigilant service to help preserve bits of history and culture.  (Thank you.). The ladies running the tour and shop the day we were there were incredibly nice. Though they had limited English, they had enough to covey meanings.
I found this place by chance while exploring the side streets near Saint Paul. Don't miss it!

Association of knowledgeable and helpful volunteers gathering and disseminating valuable information on the need for public attention to preservation of specific Paris landmarks. Also has one of the best collections of books and maps for consultation and for sale.
Great and cheap visit to discover medieval Paris and a wonderful cellier from 1300
Very interesting house and super helpful volunteers sharing their passion !

One of the oldest houses in Paris. The ground floor is Gothic with the typical hexagonal red terracotta majolica. The floors above grow over time, crowning this strange and fascinating construction with a magnificent two-level Renaissance roof. The building is home to a cultural association that promotes the culture of historic Paris. The set of publications on sale is by no means banal. A collection worthy of a university researcher. Truly incredible

Maison d'Ourscamp, in the Marais, very close to Saint Paul. The first house on this site was built in the second half of the 13th century on land received as a donation, in 1248, by the Cistercian monks of the Abbey of Notre-Dame d'Ourscamp, located near Noyon (Oise). This was their "town house." The monks used it to store the crops and various products of the abbey to later resell them in the Parisian markets. Built entirely of stone, it had a cellar of about 200 m¬≤, a room with pillars on the ground floor and an upper floor. Today, the Gothic cellar, part of the ground floor pavement and the vestiges of a large fireplace are preserved from this house. Over time, part of the initial surfaces would be rented to different people. In fact, the monks preferred to make a profit from the rents than anything else, so they rented them to merchants and artisans in the area. In 1585 it was rebuilt, to be transformed into three different houses (on the sites of the current numbers 44, 46 and 48 rue Fran√ßois-Miron). Numbers 44 and 46 survived, and are the ones visited today as "Maison d'Ourscamp". They consist of a main body with a stone fa√ßade, pierced by large mullioned windows and smaller openings. At the back there are two wooden stairs that surround a small half-timbered courtyard. There were two cantilevered toilets in them. The house has three floors and a two-level attic under a typical roof of the time. The two dormers that open the first level of the attic have pediments sculpted in the style of the 16th century. With the Revolution, the religious orders were dissolved. Ourscamp Abbey was expropriated and the house was transferred to Parisian merchants who would succeed each other over time until the 20th century, modifying the building. Little by little, the Marais, a neighborhood that had known the splendor of the private mansions of the 17th century, fell into oblivion and deteriorated considerably. During the first half of the 20th century, the degradation of the building continued. The city council identified 17 "unhealthy" blocks. With this term they referred to buildings that had to be eliminated because the living conditions inside were intolerable from all points of view: threat of ruin, lack of light, poor sanitation, etc. The Ourscamp house was in unhealthy block number 16. In 1961, the city council decided to demolish it. Many people opposed this drastic measure (demolishing the house). It was then (1963) when the association for the Safeguarding and Enhancement of Historical Paris, abbreviated "Paris Historique", appeared, which clearly positioned itself against this aberrant measure and, after long discussions, made the city reconsider its decision. . Paris accepted the restoration of the old houses, with the exception of numbers 44 and 46, considered to be in very poor condition. For these two, the restoration would be carried out entirely by the association. This association is currently in the house, already restored, except for the 13th century Gothic cellar, which is currently being fully restored, although the works have been stopped for more than a year. This basement is historical heritage.

We discovered this place yesterday. The people are welcoming and passionate. We visited the medieval cellar (currently under renovation) and the house. Again, nothing to complain about. The explanations were complete and very interesting. Answers to all our questions. Don't hesitate to go there! As a bonus, you can even buy a small book that summarizes the history of the house and its renovation.

An hour of waiting on this first heritage day was for nothing because we only see scaffolding in the basement and not the arcades which illustrate the place. Very disappointed On the other hand, a very smiling welcome Well done to the volunteers

The "Paris historique" association is based in the old Maison d'Ourscamp, rebuilt in the 16th century. on the old 13th century town house. : there remain a few visible vestiges, including a beautiful Gothic cellar currently being restored by volunteers from the Compagnonnage and others. This cellar was used by the Cistercian monks who stored all their merchandise produced at the Ourscamp Abbey (Oise) there for resale. Today the 1901 law association regularly offers conferences and guided tours of emblematic Parisian places. Books, postcards, etc. about the capital are on sale in the shop.
Superb place that you can visit and you can join the association, congratulations to all for the preservation of this heritage, thank you a thousand times

A dive into the history of France. You are welcomed by 2 charming people who give you a tour of the premises. Duration approximately 20 minutes. Interesting for history buffs. Cost = 5 euros. I do not recommend for children

We could barely speak French, all of us in the Maison had little English. And despite that, or perhaps because of that?, it was an unforgettable afternoon. We felt perfectly provided with information and impressions of this interesting piece of Paris - from committed and enthusiastic members of the association. Thank you very much!

Association created in 1963 to protect the Marais district against its destruction, and to advocate the conservation/restoration of Parisian heritage. Headquarters of the association in this house, with an eventful history and treasures to discover. Very nice tour of the place, visit rich in information and very friendly. This House will delight those curious about Parisian basements!! I absolutely recommend! Allow ‚Ç¨3 per person for entry, which is used to operate the association and to pay the Compagnons du Devoir for the restoration work on the cellar. Go for it !

Discovered during Heritage Days, I was won over by the beauty of this monument. A former palace today in the service of the Republic, and which, like so many others, contributes to the splendor of France.

I will return for a full visit when possible. Warm welcome by the volunteers. You can buy books on the history of historic Paris there for very reasonable prices. We absolutely must support this association which does everything to maintain itself!

Magnificent cellar from the 13th century. Place managed by an association, "Paris historique", since 1963. We owe it the "rescue" and restoration of the place since that date. The volunteers at reception, at the library and at the photo library are ‚Äúsharp‚Äù, passionate and available. Numerous works on the history of Paris and old maps are available for sale.

Historic place from the Middle Ages. The house of Ourscamp...16th century. Pleasant welcome. (Headquarters of the historic Paris association.) Old cellar - cellar to visit, huge, magnificent architecture with a visible well. Access to the basement, via a steep staircase. We dive into the past.... The association has a beautiful free library on historic Paris and its heritage. All lovers of old Paris and all students of history and architecture should know to enrich their research and knowledge. üìö Metro Marais St Paul.
Team of volunteers passionate about Paris, supporting a restoration project of a 13th century super cellar. Very interesting shop, with books on various subjects and beautiful maps of Paris.
A place to discover and an association which fights to preserve a house steeped in history.
Association organizing wonderful visits during heritage days I can't wait to discover the cellar once the work is finished!
A very nice visit with a fascinating guide! I highly recommend, thank you again.
Visit with a great guide for heritage day, it was great to learn lots of things about this house, the neighborhood and the association.
An extremely rare place in Paris: a great discovery, a journey to the Middle Ages accompanied by a passionate and fascinating guide.
Thank you for this very interesting visit, especially these vestiges of the Middle Ages and the kindness of the speakers, we must keep this heritage alive as long as we can.
Cistercian houses whose basement is very interesting
Interesting historical cellar with cross barrel vault.
Very interesting visit to the Beauvais hotel with a fascinating speaker. The place is very beautiful.
As welcoming as they are fascinating, the members of this association will offer you advice and discoveries through books, maps, memories and anecdotes of historic Paris.
You absolutely must visit the fantastic work in the basement On site the volunteers are all devoted to the old stones
It's worth visiting the basement. Too bad I don't have the time otherwise I would like to be part of the association
Exciting visit. Very good guide. A page of Paris history to see.
Very interesting cultural tour of the evolution of the building over the centuries. To visit without hesitation!
Always very well received with a smile and interesting discussions. To see the library on the first floor (that will be for another time ^^).
A witness to life in Paris in the Middle Ages Wide choice of books on heritage, friendly welcome and sound advice
Very interesting historic place to visit thanks to this association of historic monuments of Paris
